content:
and potassium, and it's also a good source of fiber and antioxidants. The kiwi is a small, furry fruit that grows on a vine and is native to China. It typically grows to be around 14 to 18 inches (35 to 45 cm) tall and weighs between 4.3 lbs. (0.8 to 1.9 kg) [[1](https://www.livescience.com/57813-kiwi-facts.html)].

The kiwi also contains an enzyme called actinidain or actinidin, which helps to break down protein in foods like meat, dairy, and eggs faster than other digestive enzymes. This makes it a great fruit to eat after a protein-heavy meal to aid digestion [[2](https://guide.michelin.com/us/en/article/dining-in/kiwi-fruit-facts)].

In terms of nutrition, kiwi is a low-calorie fruit that provides a good amount of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. One cup of fresh kiwi contains 108 calories, 26g of carbohydrates, 5g of dietary fiber, 2g of protein, and 1g of fat [[3](https://www.liveeatlearn.com/kiwifruit/)]. It's also high in Vitamin C and Potassium.

Another unique fact about kiwi is its high potassium content. It provides about 10% of the daily recommended intake of potassium.

In terms of availability, Kiwi is available year-round in most supermarkets, but peak kiwi season is from November to May.
